item.title: Most Singaporean women believe they are compensated fairly and that their employers value their opinions
item.description: Milieu Insight, a Southeast Asian consumer research firm, recently surveyed women in Singapore, Indonesia, and the Philippines to gauge their perceptions of workplace support, opportunities, and rewards. Concept art featuring a woman generated by dream by WOMBO. Some key takeaways include: While 67% of Singaporean women feel adequately compensated for their work, only half believe they are appropriately rewarded for exceeding expectations. Although 65% believe their employers welcome their input, only 50% feel that feedback is acted upon.

item.title: Ipsos provides insights on fatigue regarding equal rights in Singapore
item.description: A recent study by market research firm Ipsos reveals that 62% of Singaporeans believe that sufficient progress has been made in achieving equal rights for women in Singapore. This sentiment is more pronounced among men (68%) compared to women (55%). This data is drawn from a larger global study conducted by Ipsos in partnership with the Global Institute for Women’s Leadership at King’s College London for International Women’s Day 2024. The survey encompassed approximately 24,000 individuals across 31 countries, with 500 respondents from Singapore.

item.title: Policies that bring about transformation could result in an increase in the number of women in leadership positions in the APAC region
item.description: This image, created by Blue Willow, depicts a generic office discussion. The artist was not given specific genders for those sitting or standing. Recent LinkedIn data from Australia, India, and Singapore reveals a significant lack of female leadership in the Asia-Pacific region. For example, women make up almost half of Australia’s workforce but only hold 35% of leadership roles. This figure has remained stagnant since 2020. India (23%) and Singapore (38%) show similar imbalances.
